content:
‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Interesting puzzle, deceptively simple in the description

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great puzzle! Extremely well designed with tremendous attention to detail.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I'm afraid to click "Approve", but I think this task can be accepted. I had no problems understanding it. There are many tests, the author is not lazy. And I did not encounter any contradictions between tests and validators.

I love the new test cases. Count me in as an approver. I'll wait a few days and see if anybody comes up with something I'm missing. I keep looking everything over thinking that surely I can find something to comment on, but it all looks solid to me!

I'm using Algorithm X. I came up with two model variations on the first day and added a 3rd variation a couple of days later. I ran all the test cases tonight and only one of the models flies through the final handful of test cases. The other two struggle with time limits. Incredible learning opportunity for anybody studying Algorithm X.

Solved the existing tests today, was satisfied. The performance reserve is large even without optimization. You can definitely add complex cases.
A bit reminiscent of https://www.codingame.com/training/hard/horn-sat-solver.

Hi,

Nice puzzle, I have nothing to say about the statement or the tests/validators, my only comment would be that I don't think this is an hard puzzle.
I have read everything twice and I'm not finding anything to comment on. It all looks outstanding to me. I have a working solution and I look forward to the rest of the test cases. Great job!

Goal / Input / Output
* Both the terms "clue" (a hint that leads you to something) and "evidence" (information to support a claim) are used. Suggest to be consistent and stick with the word "clue", since you've used [[clues]] as the variable name.

Goal
* Please explain what the [[clue]] string means (one sentence should be enough). For example, does "MadameTurquoise (MT) noose readingroom" mean:
  (a) MT's favourite weapon the noose is found in the readingroom?
  (b) MT was seen holding the noose walking past the readingroom?
  (c) MT's fingerprints are found on the noose which is found outside the readingroom?
  (d) Or a mix of some of the above?
  (e) Or none of the above?
  (Of course some of the above are impossible, but the statement leaves room for me to interpret.)

* The phrase "Exactly one" is repeated multiple times, but I'm not sure why that's emphasised. I think most people would assume all [[clues]] given in input are distinct. Can the phrase be removed?

* Is the conclusion in the example incorrect? If the last clue means ReverandCrimson was seen holding a sword in the bedchamber, and the bedchamber is the crime scene, then the culprit should be ReverandCrimson?

Constraints
* N should be at least 2? Or else the player will be expected to handle cases of a single culprit and no other clues.

Cases
* Pending.

Title
* May I ask why you are adding "[DIFFICULTY LEVEL]" to recent new contributions? Will the difficulty level be removed from the title of a contribution after its approval?

Thanks.

I intend to remove the difficulty level from the title, yes. I've been adding it so that those commenters who aren't interested in a hard puzzle (or a reverse clash) can easily avoid those, and at the same time won't avoid all of my puzzles just because they stumbled across one that was too challenging.

Not in its current state. I've only added the simpler test cases for now. It might be interesting to publish an easier version where brute force is possible, but then I would want to abbreviate the explanation, and possibly change the rules a bit.
Now added tests I'm satisfied can't be brute forced.
That's a very interesting way of looking at it.
Great job. And it's nice to see that I still have a working solution.

It seems my first attempt was not nearly clear enough. I've completely rewritten the explanation, if you wouldn't mind taking another look.

N = 1 is a trivial case, one which states the guilty party with no additional evidence needed. I was thinking to include that, but I'll omit if you think it's too bizarre.

Ah ok, I understand now. Thanks.

I'm ok with having cases of N = 1 if the player is indeed expected to handle such cases.
Please update the variable name in the stub generator. Thanks.

I have a working solution which passes all the tests and validators. However, if I try to shuffle all the evidence lines except the first one, my solution doesn't always work. Specifically, that happens to the latter three pairs of cases. Apparently my code depends on gathering all the possible "items" from the first few evidence lines. I'm not sure whether it's a good idea to add some cases where the evidence lines are not that well-sorted, so to speak.
The plot twist is that evidence becomes evidence codes (A1, A2, B1, B2, ‚Ä¶) üòÜ
That's funny. I think "jaw dropper" is too, so I'm running with it. I'll come up with some terms like "area" and "site" so they can be renamed area A, site A, etc.
üëçüèª
